title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) — History arrived not with a whisper, but with the thunderous roar of the Charlotte Coliseum. On this night in 1998, the game itself was merely the canvas, and Dallas Mavericks guard George McCloud was the artist, painting a masterpiece that defied belief and left all who witnessed it in awe.

Despite McCloud’s transcendent, career-defining 47 points, it was the Charlotte Hornets who emerged victorious, 110-103, in a game forever remembered for one man’s singular explosion.

McCloud was simply unguardable. He operated on a different plane, shredding the Hornets’ defense with a scintillating display of shooting and slashing. Every possession was a potential highlight, every shot a dagger that silenced the home crowd. He carried the entire Mavericks offense on his back, a one-man army waging war against a full squadron.

Yet, for all his heroics, the Hornets had an answer. Anthony Mason provided a powerful, all-around counter with 20 points and 14 rebounds, while Glen Rice added 22 points of his own. Their collective effort provided just enough balance to withstand McCloud’s hurricane of points.

In the end, the Mavericks’ reliance on their superstar proved their undoing. No other Dallas player scored more than 11 points. As the final minutes ticked away, McCloud, perhaps finally succumbing to the monumental effort, could not single-handedly close the gap.

The final score belonged to Charlotte, but the narrative belonged irrevocably to George McCloud. He left everything on the floor in a breathtaking, 47-point tour de force—a staggering individual performance that soared above the final result and etched his name into the annals of a night where one man nearly conquered five.
